kafka_bus_python Package¶

bus_message Module¶

Created on May 19, 2015

@author: paepcke

class kafka_bus_python.bus_message.BusMessage(pythonStruct, topicName=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

While messages can be passed around within a module as a JSON string, this class provides an alternative. Messages can be encapsulated in an instance of this class while in use within a bus module. The instance ensures that text is in UTF-8. More conveniences could/should be added to this class.

Example for a bus module that subscribes to a topic, and then echoes all messages to the screen.

DEFAULT_TOPIC = 'example_use'¶
printMessage(topicName, msgText, msgOffset)[source]¶

This method is called whenever a message in topic self.topicName is published by anyone on the bus. It just prints the message topic and content.

Parameters:
  • topicName (string) – name of topic to which the arriving msg belongs
  • msgText (string) – text part of the message. Could be JSON, or anything else.
  • msgOffset (int) – position of message in the topic’s message history

kafka_bus Module¶

Created on May 19, 2015

@author: paepcke

class kafka_bus_python.kafka_bus.BusAdapter(kafkaHost=None, kafkaPort=None, loggingLevel=10, logFile=None, kafkaGroupId='school_bus')[source]¶

Bases: object

The BusAdapter class is intended to be imported to bus modules. Instances of this class provide the software bus illusion over Kafka. Public methods are:

  • publish()
  • waitForMessage()
  • subscribeToTopic()
  • unSubscribeFromTopic()
  • addTopicListener()
  • removeTopicListener()
  • mySubscriptions()
  • returnError()
  • close()

Clients of this class may install multiple listeners for any given topic. The publish() method may be used asynchronously, just to send a message to subscribing modules on the bus, or synchronously like a remote procedure call.

The BusAdapter wraps payloads into a JSON structure as follows:

'id'     : <RFC 4122 UUID Version 4>   # e.g. 'b0f4259e-3d01-44bd-9eb3-25981c2dc643'
'type'   : {req | resp}
'status' : { OK | ERROR }
'time'   : <ISO 8601>                  # e.g. '2015-05-31T17:13:41.957350'
'content': <text>

It is the responsibility of listener functions to strip this header away, if desired. For an example see echo_service.EchoServer’s echoRequestDelivery() method.

addTopicListener(topicName, deliveryCallback)[source]¶

Add a listener function for a topic for which a subscription already exists. Parameter deliverCallback must be a function accepting parameters: topicName, rawResult, msgOffset It is an error to call the method without first having subscribed to the topic.

Parameters:
  • topicName (String) – name of topic to add
  • deliveryCallback (<function(topicName, rawResult, msgOffset)) – function to call when message to this topic arrives
Raises NameError:
 

if caller has not previously subscribed to topicName.
close()[source]¶

Cleanup. All threads are stopped. Kafka connection is closed.

publish(busMessage, topicName=None, sync=False, msgId=None, msgType='req', timeout=None, auth=None)[source]¶

Publish either a string or a BusMessage object. If busMessage is a string, then the caller is responsible for ensuring that the string is UTF-8, and a topic name must be provided.

If busMessage is a BusMessage object, then that object contains all the required information. In this case, parameter topicName overrides a topic name that might be stored in the BusMessage.

Messages are wrapped in a JSON structure that provides ‘id’, ‘type’, ‘time’, and ‘content’ fields. The ‘content’ field will contain the message payload.

Two ways of using this method: asynchronously, and synchronously. In asynchronous invocation the passed-in message is published, and this method returns immediately. For this type of invocation just provide argument busMessage, and possibly topicName, if busMessage is a string.

Synchronous invocation is just like a remote procedure call. In synchronous invocation the passed-in message is published, and this method will wait for a return message that carries the same message ID, and is of message type ‘resp’. This method then returns the content of the returned message; the surrounding wrapper (time/msgId/msgType...) is stripped.

Parameters:
  • busMessage ({string | BusMessage}) – string or BusMessage to publish
  • topicName ({string | None}) – name of topic to publish to. If None, then parameter must be a BusMessage object that contains an associated topic name.
  • sync (boolean) – if True, call will not return till answer received, or timeout (if given) has expired).
  • msgId (string) – if this publish() call is a response to a prior request, the request message’s ID must be the id of the response. In that case the caller can use this parameter to provide the ID. If None, a new message ID is generated.
  • msgType – value for the message type field of the outgoing message. Usually this is ‘req’, but when calling publish() to return a result to a prior request, then set this argument to ‘resp’.
  • timeout (float) – timeout after which synchronous call should time out. if sync is False, the timeout parameter is ignored.
  • auth (not yet known) – reserved for later authentication mechanism.
Returns:

value is only defined for synchronous invocation.
Return type:

string
Raises:
  • ValueError – if targeted topic name is not provided in a msg object, or explicitly in the topicName parameter.
  • ValueError – if illegal message type is passed in.
  • BadInformation – if Kafka does not recognize the provided topic and Kafka is not configured to create topics on the fly.
  • SyncCallTimedOut – if no response is received to a synchronous call within the provided timeout period.
  • SyncCallRuntimeError – if a message received in response to a synchronous call cannot be parsed.
removeTopicListener(topicName, deliveryCallback)[source]¶

Remove a topic listener function from a topic. It is a no-op to call this method with a topic that has not been subscribed to, or with a deliveryCallback function that was never added to the topic.

Parameters:
  • topicName –
  • deliveryCallback –
returnError(req_key, topicName, errMsg)[source]¶

Convencience method when handling an incoming message. Returns a message that is marked as an error return.

Parameters:
  • req_key (String) – key of the incoming message; it will be used in the return message as well.
  • topicName (String) – name of topic to use in the return message
  • errMsg (String) – error message to include in the return message
subscribeToTopic(topicName, deliveryCallback=None, kafkaLiveCheckTimeout=30)[source]¶

Fork a new thread that keeps waiting for any messages on the topic of the given name. Stop listening for the topic by calling unsubscribeFromTropic().

For convenience, a deliveryCallback function may be passed, saving a subsequent call to addTopicListener(). See addTopicListener() for details.

If deliveryCallback is absent or None, then method _deliverResult() in this class will be used. That method is intended to be a placeholder with no side effects.

It is a no-op to call this method multiple times for the same topic.

Parameters:
  • topicName (string) – official name of topic to listen for.
  • deliveryCallback (function) – a function that takes two args: a topic name, and a topic content string.
  • kafkaLiveCheckTimeout (float) – timeout in (fractional) seconds to wait when checking for a live Kafka server being available.
Raises KafkaServerNotFound:
 

when no Kafka server responds
unsubscribeFromTopic(topicName)[source]¶

Unsubscribes from topic. Stops the topic’s thread, and removes it from bookkeeping so that the Thread object will be garbage collected. Same for the Event object used by the thread to signal message arrival.

Calling this method for a topic that is already unsubscribed is a no-op.

Parameters:topicName (string) – name of topic to subscribe from
waitForMessage(topicName, timeout=None)[source]¶

Block till a message on the given topic arrives. It is an error to call this method on a topic to which the caller has not previously subscribed.

Parameters:
  • topicName –
  • timeout (float) – seconds (or fractions of second) to wait.
Returns:

True if a message arrived in time, else returnes False
Return type:

boolean
Raises NameError:
 

on attempt to wait for a topic for which no subscription exists.

exception kafka_bus_python.kafka_bus_exceptions.InsufficientInformation(msg, errorDetail=None)[source]¶

Bases: kafka_bus_python.kafka_bus_exceptions.KafkaBusException

A bus message does not contain all the information required by the bus protocol, or a bus module. Instance variable ‘errorDetail’ contains the missing field name.

addListener(callback)[source]¶

Add a listener who will be notified with any message that arrives on the topic. See addTopicListener() in BusAdapter for details on parameters.

Parameters:callback (function) – function with two args: a topic name, and a string that is the message content.
fetch_message_max_bytes = 1073741824¶
listeners()[source]¶

Return all the callback functions that will be called each time a message arrives.

:returns list of registered callback functions.

removeListener(callback)[source]¶

Remove the specified function from the callbacks to notify upon message arrivals. It is a no-op to remove a non-existing listener.

Parameters:callback (Function) – callback function to remove.
run()[source]¶

Hang on Kafka message arrival. Whenever a message arrives, set() the threading.Event object, if one was provided to the __init__() method. Then all all the registered delivery functions in turn.

Periodically check whether self.done is True, indicating that thread should stop.
